review.title: Empirical Study of Artificial Fish Swarm Algorithm
review.abstract: Artificial fish swarm algorithm (AFSA) is one of the swarm intelligence optimization algorithms that works based on population and stochastic search. In order to achieve acceptable result, there are many parameters needs to be adjusted in AFSA. Among these parameters, visual and step are very significant in view of the fact that artificial fish basically move based on these parameters. In standard AFSA, these two parameters remain constant until the algorithm termination. Large values of these parameters increase the capability of algorithm in global search, while small values improve the local search ability of the algorithm. In this paper, we empirically study the performance of the AFSA and different approaches to balance between local and global exploration have been tested based on the adaptive modification of visual and step during algorithm execution. The proposed approaches have been evaluated based on the four well-known benchmark functions. Experimental results show considerable positive impact on the performance of AFSA.

sections.text: Reza Azizi, International Journal of Computing, Communications and Networking, 3 (1), January - March 2014, 01-07 ABSTRACT The Swarm Intelligence Optimization Algorithm (AFSA) is one of the swarm intelligence optimization algorithms that work on the basis of population and stochastic search. In order to achieve an acceptable result, many parameters need to be adjusted in AFSA. Among these parameters, the visual and step-by-step parameters are very important given that artificial fish essentially move on the basis of these parameters. In standard AFSA, these two parameters remain constant until the completion of the algorithm. Large values of these parameters increase the ability of the algorithm in global search, while small values improve the local searchability of the algorithm. In this paper, we empirically examine the performance of AFSA and various approaches to balancing local and global exploration based on the adaptive modification of image and step during the execution of the algorithm.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 2. ARTIFICIAL FISH SWARM ALGORITHM
sections.text: In the underwater world, based on their individual or shoal search, fish can find areas with more food. Inspired by this characteristic, the Artificial Fish (AF) model is represented by prey, free movement, swarm and behavior. AF searches the problem area by these behaviors. AF lives in this problem area. AFSA's objective function is to find maximum food density. As Figure 1 shows, AF observes external concepts with their visual perception. The current position of AF is represented by the vector X = (X1, X2,..., Xn). The visual corresponds to the visual area of the AF and Xv is a designated position in the visual area to which the AF chooses to move. If Xv has a better food density than the current position, the AF moves one step towards Xv, resulting in a shift of the AF from X to Xnext. Otherwise, the current position of the AF is better than Xv, it chooses a different position in its visual position from < the fit density is equal to the distance between the food density; the X in the fit density.

sections.heading: 3. ARTIFICIAL FISH SWARM ALGORITHM WITH
sections.text: VARIABLE VISUAL AND STEP In AFSA, artificial fish seek the problem environment in their visual environment based on the behavior and then they move to the target through a random value of their step. In standard AFSA, determining the initial values of the step and visual essentially affect the end result. Values of separation parameters remain constant and equal to the initial values during the execution of the algorithm. By having large initial values for these parameters, artificial fish move faster toward the global optimum. That is, artificial fish are able to seek larger surroundings around them and move with larger steps. Therefore, artificial fish are able to escape from the local optima under such circumstances. However, there are some deficiencies in large values of the step and the visual. Accuracy and steadfastness of the algorithm decrease in such a situation. In fact, the algorithm acts better in the global search, but after finding itself in the global position, it is not appropriate to the local one.

sections.heading: 3.1 Linear Movement Weight
sections.text: In this method, MW is a positive function that fluctuates between a minimum and a maximum and is calculated according to the current iteration and final iteration number. In the case of linearly decreasing MW [16], MW corresponds to the maximum value at the beginning of the algorithm. During the execution of the algorithm, this amount is reduced linearly to the minimum value based on the iteration number. MW in each iteration is calculated according to Equation 3. In the case of linearly increasing MW [17], the first MW is set to the minimum value, then increases linearly during execution and finally reaches the maximum value. MW in each iteration is specified according to Equation 4: MinMax Max Max Max Max Max MinItr MWItrItrItrItrItrMW (3) MinMax Max Max Max MaxItr MWMMItrItrItrItrItrItrItrMW (4), with border being a random value between 0 and 1 with normal distribution.

sections.heading: 3.2 Random Movement Weight
sections.text: In random MW [18], MW is a random number between two values: minimum and maximum. In each iteration, the random value of MW is calculated using the following equation: MinMaxMinItr MWMWRandMWMW (5)

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTS AND ANALYSIS
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it will only be a matter of time before it is ready, until it is ready.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we applied a parameter called Movement Weight (MW) to the Artificial Fish Swarm Algorithm (AFSA). Experimental results show the positive effects of this parameter on the performance of AFSA. It is easy to see that AFSA can operate better than standard AFSA with a suitable MW parameter. In addition, time-varying MW and a random MW lead to a significant improvement in AFSA performance. Various simulations have been conducted to support the competence of the MW.

referenceMentions.context: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [1] and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) [2] are two most well-known methods.
Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [1] and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) [2] are two most well-known methods.
Artificial fish swarm algorithm (AFSA) [3], proposed by Li Xiao Lei in 2002, is a stochastic population-based algorithm motivated by intelligent collective behavior of fish groups in nature.
It has been applied on different problems including machine learning [4,5,6], PID controlling [7], wireless sensor networks [8], image segmentation [9], data clustering [10,11] and scheduling [12].

Beforehand, parameter called inertia weight has been applied on particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm by Shi and Eberhart [13].
Inertia weight, which can be a positive constant number [13], or a positive linear or non-linear function [14], or others [15], significantly improved the performance of algorithm.

metadata.abstractText: Artificial fish swarm algorithm (AFSA) is one of the swarm intelligence optimization algorithms that works based on population and stochastic search. In order to achieve acceptable result, there are many parameters needs to be adjusted in AFSA. Among these parameters, visual and step are very significant in view of the fact that artificial fish basically move based on these parameters. In standard AFSA, these two parameters remain constant until the algorithm termination. Large values of these parameters increase the capability of algorithm in global search, while small values improve the local search ability of the algorithm. In this paper, we empirically study the performance of the AFSA and different approaches to balance between local and global exploration have been tested based on the adaptive modification of visual and step during algorithm execution. The proposed approaches have been evaluated based on the four well-known benchmark functions. Experimental results show considerable positive impact on the performance of AFSA.
